section.title: wish / if only
section.sectiontitle: Use wish to say you want something to be different from the reality. To talk about a present (or permanent) wish, use wish + Past Simple.
section.text2: I'd like to have a brother.
section.text2a: I wish I had a brother.
section.sectiontitle2: Use wish + had + past participle to describe a wish about the past.
section.text3: I'm tired because I went to bed late.
section.text3a: I wish I had gone to bed early.
section.text4: She drank too much coffee and didn't sleep.
section.text4a: She wishes she hadn't drunk so much coffee.

section.title: wish / if only
section.sectiontitle: Use wish + object + would to say you want something to change because it makes you angry.
section.text1a: I wish you would be quiet!
section.text2a: I wish you would arrive on time.
section.sectiontitle2: Use wish + could to describe an ability you want but don't have.
section.text3: I like football, but I can't play it.
section.text3a: I wish I could play football.
section.text4: She has problems getting up early in the morning.
section.text4a: She wishes she could get up early in the morning.

section.title: wish / if only
section.sectiontitle: Use if only instead of wish. If only is a stronger and more emotional expression. The grammar is the same.
section.text1: I wish I had more money.
section.text1a: If only I had more money!
section.text2: I wish you hadn't come here.
section.text2a: If only you hadn't come here!
